"As Lenin once observed, 'Sometimes decades pass and nothing happens; and then sometimes weeks pass and decades happen.'”

And as Reagan once observed, "Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall!" and in the blink of an eye, the wall was gone and the Evil Empire was gone. Then they gave the aforementioned Gorbachev the Nobel Peace Prize for losing the Cold War.

I feel that the article is misrepresenting the tax figures from the mid-80s. Tax cuts negotiated by the Reagan Administration brought the tax rate down to 50%. The article fails to address that fact that these cuts influenced the economic boom of the mid-80s. Yes, the economy grew with a marginal tax rate of 50%, but that was a result of those tax rates being lower than they previously were, thus allowing wealthier people to invest more money in the market and other business opportunities. This should not be used as an argument for raising taxes. It is a clear example of misrepresenting the facts to make a point in the author's favor.

You may not have noticed, but the "damage and corruption" are already rampant. Throw in heinous economic inequality and you've got yourself a banana republic. Welcome to our brave new world.

Money is not speech, because if it is defined thus, then those without money must be mute and incapable of communication - a blatantly false assertion. For example, posting comments on internet news sites does not cost any money (although some infrastructure is required). Neither does writing letters to public officials, or organizing grassroots political groups.

Likewise, corporations are not people. If corporations were people, then no corporation could own another, and all holding companies, subsidiaries, etc. would have to be dissolved immediately (as per anti-slavery laws).

A corporation is nothing more than an absentee ownership arrangement which protects the owners (shareholders) from any legal liability, instead handing that liability off to the corporation's management (insiders) and assets.

The notion that such a legal fiction could be defined as a 'person' entitled to spend as much money as it wanted on buying politicians is beyond ludicrous, and shows that the Supreme Court has abandoned rationality and respect for the impartial rule of law in favor of political partisanship.

Clearly, allowing corporate entities (say, the the British East India Company) to buy elections is not what the framers of the Constitution had in mind. They were well aware that such entities were profoundly anti-democratic and were in reality little more than puppets that obeyed the British aristocracy that was oppressing the colonies.

It's true that corporations have gained ever-greater political power ever since the Court defined them as 'people' in the late 19th century, but much of their power was rolled back by trust-busters like Teddy Roosevelt. Now, new legal rulings have put us on a course back to the Robber Baron era.

This recent sharp turn away from Constitutional law and towards political partisanship by the Court is unprecedented since the end of that earlier, pre-world war era. Perhaps the real turning point was the 5-4 selection of GW Bush as President (in direct reversal of traditional conservative support for state's rights in election matters) in 2000.

That decision will likely be fingered by future historians as one of the very worst in the entire history of the Court, one that set the stage for the appointment of two highly suspect jurors, Roberts and Alioto, who have continued to steer the Court into politically partisan waters, while continually enhancing the power of corporate conglomerates (see Citizens United, for example).

Many people lost their respect for the Supreme Court as an impartial arbiter of the rule of law as a result of Bush vs. Gore decision, that's certain enough - and the downhill spiral has continued from that point.

This decision simply continues this Supreme Court's corruption of our franchise that the Citizens United decision represented. The Court allows those with deep pockets to magnify their voices and influence elections. In doing so it devalues MY influence.

Wow! What a stretch of the imagination! What you're really describing here are not metaphors but idiomatic figures of speech, some of them anthropomorphic. We do not use these idioms, as you suggest, in an "imprecise" way or as a means to "distance" ourselves from our subjects. They are simply common ways of expressing common phenomena. At some point, what may once have been a novel metaphor simply becomes a synonym for a common word.

Everyone will know what I mean when I say your thesis on metaphors is "half-baked," and NO ONE will think of cakes taken from the oven too soon. In fact, if I took my cake from the oven too soon & it fell, I would not describe it as "half-baked," because "half-baked" no longer refers to the state of a cake or a pie or a chicken.

When we describe a stock market "dip," everyone knows exactly what we're talking about. There's no psychological distance between "dip" and "down," other than that they are different parts of speech. Indeed, "dip" is more descriptive than "down." "Dip" evokes a mental picture of a graph, whereas "down" is a more general term & can describe a direction of various types of descents.

What you are describing is not poetry at all. It's the ordinary evolution of words. T. S. Eliot and Ezra Pound believed a poet must "make it new," and in repurposing words, that's what they did. Conversely, using common idioms to describe common phenomena is quintessentially prosaic. Digest that.

Many of the metaphors you mention are uttered or (worse) written out of laziness, are the opposite of creative speech, and are simply clichés that we pass along without thinking. Pedestrian, yes; but the antithesis of poetry.

..." Most of us are not good at understanding new things, so we grasp them imperfectly by relating them metaphorically to things that already exist."

And, more importantly, Mr. Brooks, most of us are not good at understanding ourselves or other people! Self awareness and awareness of other people is so much of what is lacking in our "me-first" culture. People are being "had" by metaphors. They spout metaphors without understanding what they really mean. What our cultural metaphors tend to describe are "winners" and "losers." That is what is important in America. Are you UP, or are you DOWN?

What is missing in your essay is the idea that "people are people wherever they go," and that a person can be UP one day and DOWN the next. These are fleeting and shallow metaphors you describe and do not address the meaning of what it is to be human.

As a thoughtful and concerned philosopher (my husband) said some years ago: "We human beings are wrecks!" Yes we are! We seem intent on destroying our precious earth and on making wars and abusing other people without conscience. What would be your metaphor for that sad, unnecessary, crazy truth?

They have their exits and their entrances,
And one man in his time plays many parts,
His acts being seven ages.

Rather than just making a pleasant poetic link between two things in the real world, religions use metaphors to give substance to things that exist only in the imagination. Rhetorical devices, like metaphors, similes, allegories, and analogies, can provide the illusion of substance where none exists. The "veil" metaphor is a case in point. It makes a virtue of the vagueness religions must rely on when describing God. After all, we all know looking through a veil clouds and distorts our vision, so obviously now we know why God can't be seen clearly. It's the veil.

If you point out that there is no veil, you can get into quite a bit of trouble. Ask Galileo about the seriousness with which the Church takes its metaphors. By looking through a telescope at moons circling Jupiter, Galileo punctured the holy metaphor that Man was the Center of All Things. As a result, he lived under house arrest for the last eight years of his life, and had to recant what he knew to be true.

Metaphors can be used to increase understanding of the real world, or they can be used to construct worlds that are not real, worlds that are all scaffolding and no structure. Metaphorically speaking, that is.

Too simplified on/about metaphor. You write: "In his superb book “Judaism: A Way of Being,” David Gelernter notes that Jewish thought uses the image of a veil to describe how Jews perceive God — as a presence to be sensed but not seen, which is intimate and yet apart." Why is the book superb? That's no metaphor, but praise; In this instance, the Hebraic "veil" makes no sense: The Hebraic god is always an absent god, so perhaps that "veil" is not a metaphor but a concept that installs alienation--maybe the Hebraic god is the devil? In other words, metaphors are inseparable from myths and truths, lies and errors, cognition and illusion, etc. etc. Starting with Gorgias in Sicily around 550 b.c., all the ancient rhetoricians knew that it was healthy to be suspicious about poetics. Gorgias called metaphor a "kidnapping" of thought. And metaphor was never stand-alone: the tropological dimension includes synecdoche, metonyms, ironies, etc., and metaphor is only one of many twists and turns intrinsic to the POLITICS OF LANGUAGE.

Sorry, but after the last few columns heaping praise on Paul Ryan's monstrous budget proposal -- "a bold step" that starts a "great journey," or so sayeth Mr. Brooks -- I can't even stomach a supposedly non-political David Brooks column. His welcome is so thoroughly worn out that I can't imagine ever enjoying another piece of his writing. It's a shame -- but then again, so is his tendency to produce starry-eyed hagiographies of Republican nitwits.

In his book “Faces in the Clouds”, Stewart Guthrie writes about our propensity to anthropomorphize what we see. We see human aims when they do not exist but Kathryn Schifferdecker’s monograph “Out of the Whirlwind: Creation Theology in the Book of Job” reminds us that even in our religions traditions we are not always the focus and purpose of the universe.

I appreciate work by George Lakoff and Mark Johnson; they are on to something and so are you to remind us how our metaphors shape our thinking and action. We cannot do critical thinking unless we look closely at our metaphors. By the way, Paul Ricoeur and Philip Wheelwright did excellent and helpful work on this theme as did Donald Davidson.
